TheÂ horizonÂ orÂ skylineÂ is the apparent line that separatesÂ earthÂ fromÂ sky, the line that divides all visible directions into two categories: those that intersect the Earth’s surface, and those that do not. At many locations, the true horizon is obscured by trees, buildings, mountains, etc., and the resulting intersection of earth and sky is called theÂ visible horizon. When looking at a sea from a shore, the part of the sea closest to the horizon is called theÂ offing. The wordÂ horizonÂ derives from theÂ GreekÂ “á½ÏÎ¯Î¶ÏÎ½ ÎºÏÎºÎ»Î¿Ï”Â horizÅn kyklos, “separating circle”,from the verbÂ á½ÏÎ¯Î¶ÏÂ horizÅ, “to divide”, “to separate”, and that from “á½ÏÎ¿Ï” (oros), “boundary, landmark”.

Historically, the distance to the visible horizon has long been vital to survival and successful navigation, especially at sea, because it determined an observer’s maximum range of vision and thus ofÂ communication, with all the obvious consequences for safety and the transmission of information that this range implied. This importance lessened with the development of theÂ radioÂ and theÂ telegraph, but even today, when flying anÂ aircraftÂ underÂ visual flight rules, a technique calledÂ attitude flyingÂ is used to control the aircraft, where the pilot uses the visual relationship between the aircraft’s nose and the horizon to control the aircraft. A pilot can also retain his or herÂ spatial orientationÂ by referring to the horizon.

In many contexts, especiallyÂ perspectiveÂ drawing, the curvature of theÂ EarthÂ is disregarded and the horizon is considered the theoretical line to which points on anyÂ horizontal planeÂ converge (when projected onto the picture plane) as their distance from the observer increases. For observers nearÂ sea levelÂ the difference between thisÂ geometrical horizonÂ (which assumes a perfectly flat, infinite ground plane) and theÂ true horizonÂ (which assumes aÂ spherical EarthÂ surface) is imperceptible to the naked eye dubiousÂ âÂ discuss but for someone on a 1000-meter hill looking out to sea the true horizon will be about a degree below a horizontal line.
